metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of the Heihe River Basin integrated observatory network (phenology camera observation dataset of Daman superstation, 2018)
metadata.description:
The dataset contains phenological camera observation data collected at the Arou Superstation in the midstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 13 to November 16, 2018. The instrument was developed with data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures high-quality data with a resolution of 1280×720 by looking-downward. The calculation of the greenness index and phenology are following 3 steps: (1) calculate the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)) according to the region of interest, (2) perform gap-filling for the invalid values, filtering and smoothing, and (3) determine the key phenological parameters according to the growth curve fitting (such as the growth season start date, Peak, growth season end, etc.) There are also 3 steps for coverage data processing: (1) select images with less intense illumination, (2) divide the image into vegetation and soil, and (3) calculate the proportion of vegetation pixels in each image in the calculation area. After the time series data is extracted, the original coverage data is smoothed and filtered according to the time window specified by the user, and the filtered result is the final time series coverage. This data set includes relative greenness index (GCC), phenological phase and fractional cover (FC).
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor phenological changes in arid and semi-arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to monitor phenological changes in arid and semi-arid regions is the use of phenological cameras that capture images at specified intervals. These cameras, like the one in the Heihe River Basin, are mounted vertically and capture high-resolution images (1280x720) to calculate relative greenness indices such as the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC). This allows for the determination of key phenological parameters by analyzing the images for vegetation coverage and growth stages.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when collecting data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge encountered when collecting data in oasis-desert ecosystems includes the ecological environment degradation such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification. These issues are prevalent in many inland river basins along the Silk Road, like the Tarim River basin and the Lake Urmia basin, and can complicate long-term ecological monitoring and data collection efforts.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that captures both meteorological and ecological parameters in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that captures both meteorological and ecological parameters in arid regions is the dataset from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin. This dataset includes long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary hydrometeorological data, vegetation, and soil parameters. It is collected from multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations and aims to provide comprehensive insights into ecosystem interactions in oasis-desert areas.

Definition.Question: How is data pre-processing conducted for determining vegetation coverage in ecological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Data pre-processing for determining vegetation coverage involves selecting images captured under optimal lighting conditions, segmenting these images into vegetation and soil components, and calculating the proportion of vegetation pixels within the area of interest. This proportion represents the coverage for the corresponding image, which is then smoothed using a specified time window to produce a time series of coverage data.

Interpretation.Question: What rules can be inferred about the interaction between oasis and desert ecosystems based on observed energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The study of oasis and desert ecosystems suggests that these areas play a crucial role in maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange is essential for achieving carbon neutrality and ecological security. Long-term datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems provide vital insights into these interactions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the observed patterns in vegetation cover and phenological changes from phenocam data inform sustainable management practices in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Phenocam data, which captures vegetation cover and phenological changes such as growth season start and end, can inform sustainable management by highlighting shifts in vegetation dynamics. This information is critical for maintaining ecological balance and supporting socioeconomic development in oasis–desert systems, particularly under climate change pressures.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges are suggested by the data collection methods used for understanding hydrometeorological and soil parameters in arid and semiarid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in data collection methods for hydrometeorological and soil parameters include managing the ecological degradation crisis, such as drying rivers and intensified desertification. Observational datasets require robust data processing and quality control to ensure accurate long-term monitoring and to address the impacts of climate change on these fragile ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of using long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert systems on the strategies for achieving sustainable oasis development?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert systems can lead to more informed strategies for achieving sustainable oasis development. This understanding can guide policy-making and resource management aimed at achieving carbon neutrality and ecological security in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of integrating phenology camera observations with data transmission capabilities in environmental monitoring networks?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to accurately monitor and analyze key phenological parameters such as the start and end of the growing season, as well as peak growth, by calculating relative greenness indices and smoothing data to capture critical growth stages for ecological stability and agricultural productivity.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it crucial to maintain long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial to understand the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are significant for achieving carbon neutrality and supporting sustainable development and ecological security in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the procedure for calculating the key phenological parameters from the phenology camera data in an arid region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves calculating the relative greenness index (GCC) using the formula GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, B are the red, green, and blue pixel values of the image. This is followed by filling in invalid values and smoothing the data. Finally, key phenological parameters such as the start of the growing season, peak, and end of the growing season are determined by fitting a growth curve.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the vegetation cover data preprocessed and filtered to produce a reliable time series in dryland ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing involves selecting images with moderate lighting, segmenting the images into vegetation and soil, and calculating the proportion of vegetation pixels in the region of interest. The raw cover data is then smoothed using user-specified time windows to produce a reliable time series.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are taken to measure and validate energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes are measured using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The procedure includes acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data and hydrometeorological data from automated weather stations, followed by data processing, applying quality controls, and archiving and sharing the data for further analysis.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of detailed phenological data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The development of phenological cameras with integrated data acquisition and transmission functions, such as those used in the Heihe River Basin, has enabled the collection of detailed phenological data in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers enhance the accuracy of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux measurements in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, providing precise measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are crucial for understanding oasis–desert ecosystem interactions.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources are necessary to conduct long-term environmental observations in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Enablement.Answer: Conducting long-term environmental observations in these regions requires a suite of observational datasets, including energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, supported by automatic weather stations and groundwater table data.

Expectation.Question: What are some potential challenges faced in collecting and processing data in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in arid and semiarid inland river basins include the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, particularly in regions like the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: It is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is important for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality and for supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using phenology cameras for data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Phenology cameras are effective for data collection in arid and semiarid regions as they provide high-resolution images that can be used to calculate the green chromatic coordinate, enabling detailed analysis of vegetation changes over time. The ability to specify shooting frequency and integrate data transmission functions enhances their utility in capturing dynamic environmental processes.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring the accuracy and quality of long-term observational data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in ensuring the accuracy and quality of long-term observational data in oasis–desert ecosystems include managing ecological degradation such as land desertification, ensuring consistency in data collection over time, addressing the potential for equipment malfunctions, and dealing with the variability of environmental conditions that can affect data integrity.

Judgmental.Answer: Potential strategies to expand or refine datasets include increasing the number of observation stations, integrating advanced remote sensing technologies, employing more sophisticated data processing and quality control methods, and collaborating with international research initiatives to share and compare data across similar ecosystems.
